me.lerch.alexa.state.handler

Class AWSDynamoStateHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.lerch.alexa.state.handler.AlexaSessionStateHandler
      • me.lerch.alexa.state.handler.AWSDynamoStateHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AlexaStateHandler

    public class AWSDynamoStateHandler
extends AlexaSessionStateHandler
    As this handler works in the user and application scope it persists all models to a AWS DynamoDB table. This handler reads and writes state for AlexaStateModels and considers all its fields annotated with AlexaSaveState-tags. This handler derives from the AlexaSessionStateHandler thus it reads and writes state out of DynamoDB also to your Alexa session.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AWSDynamoStateHandler

        public AWSDynamoStateHandler(com.amazon.speech.speechlet.Session session)
        The most convenient constructor just takes the Alexa session. An AWS client for accessing DynamoDB will make use of all defaults in regards to credentials and region. The credentials used in this client need permission for reading, writing and removing items from a DynamoDB table and also the right to create a table. On the very first read or write operation of this handler it creates a table named like your Alexa App Id. The table created consist of a hash-key and a sort-key. If you don't want this handler to auto-create a table provide the name of an existing table in DynamoDB in another constructor.
        Parameters:
        session - The Alexa session of your current skill invocation.

      • AWSDynamoStateHandler

        public AWSDynamoStateHandler(com.amazon.speech.speechlet.Session session,
                             com.amazonaws.services.dynamodbv2.AmazonDynamoDBClient awsClient)
        Takes the Alexa session and a AWS client which is set up for the correct AWS region. The credentials used in this client need permission for reading, writing and removing items from a DynamoDB table and also the right to create a table. On the very first read or write operation of this handler it creates a table named like your Alexa App Id. The table created consist of a hash-key and a sort-key. If you don't want this handler to auto-create a table provide the name of an existing table in DynamoDB in another constructor.
        Parameters:
        session - The Alexa session of your current skill invocation.
        awsClient - An AWS client capable of creating DynamoDB table plus reading, writing and removing items.

      • AWSDynamoStateHandler

        public AWSDynamoStateHandler(com.amazon.speech.speechlet.Session session,
                             java.lang.String tableName)
        Takes the Alexa session and a table. An AWS client for accessing DynamoDB will make use of all defaults in regards to credentials and region. The credentials used in this client need permission for reading, writing and removing items from the given DynamoDB table. The table needs a string hash-key with name model-class and a string sort-key of name amzn-user-id. The option of providing an existing table to this handler prevents it from checking its existence which might end up with a better performance. You also don't need to provide permission of creating a DynamoDB table to the credentials of the given AWS client.
        Parameters:
        session - The Alexa session of your current skill invocation.
        tableName - An existing table accessible by the client and with string hash-key named model-class and a string sort-key named amzn-user-id.

      • AWSDynamoStateHandler

        public AWSDynamoStateHandler(com.amazon.speech.speechlet.Session session,
                             com.amazonaws.services.dynamodbv2.AmazonDynamoDBClient awsClient,
                             java.lang.String tableName)
        Takes the Alexa session and a AWS client which is set up for the correct AWS region. The credentials used in this client need permission for reading, writing and removing items from the given DynamoDB table. The table needs a string hash-key with name model-class and a string sort-key of name amzn-user-id. The option of providing an existing table to this handler prevents it from checking its existence which might end up with a better performance. You also don't need to provide permission of creating a DynamoDB table to the credentials of the given AWS client.
        Parameters:
        session - The Alexa session of your current skill invocation.
        awsClient - An AWS client capable of reading, writing and removing items of the given DynamoDB table.
        tableName - An existing table accessible by the client and with string hash-key named model-class and a string sort-key named amzn-user-id.

      • AWSDynamoStateHandler

        public AWSDynamoStateHandler(com.amazon.speech.speechlet.Session session,
                             com.amazonaws.services.dynamodbv2.AmazonDynamoDBClient awsClient,
                             long readCapacityUnits,
                             long writeCapacityUnits)
        Takes the Alexa session, an AWS client which is set up for the correct AWS region. The credentials used in this client need permission for reading, writing and removing items from a DynamoDB table and also the right to create a table. On the very first read or write operation of this handler it creates a table named like your Alexa App Id. The table created consist of a hash-key and a sort-key. If you don't want this handler to auto-create a table provide the name of an existing table in DynamoDB in another constructor.
        Parameters:
        session - The Alexa session of your current skill invocation.
        awsClient - An AWS client capable of creating DynamoDB table plus reading, writing and removing items.
        readCapacityUnits - Read capacity for the table which is applied only on creation of table (what happens at the very first read or write operation with this handler)
        writeCapacityUnits - Write capacity for the table which is applied only on creation of table (what happens at the very first read or write operation with this handler)

    • Method Detail

      • writeModel

        public void writeModel(AlexaStateModel model)
                throws AlexaStateException
        The given model will be saved in the persistence store according to its AlexaStateSave-annotations. If you set up an Id for the model it will be accessible with it on later on reads to the handler.
        Specified by:
        writeModel in interface AlexaStateHandler
        Overrides:
        writeModel in class AlexaSessionStateHandler
        Parameters:
        model - Your model which needs to be a type of AlexaStateModel
        Throws:
        AlexaStateException - Wraps all inner exceptions and gives you context related to handler and model

      • removeModel

        public void removeModel(AlexaStateModel model)
                 throws AlexaStateException
        The given model will be removed from the persistence store. If it's not existing in the store nothing happens. Be aware of the Id set in the model as the removal will only affect the model with this id.
        Specified by:
        removeModel in interface AlexaStateHandler
        Overrides:
        removeModel in class AlexaSessionStateHandler
        Parameters:
        model - Your model which needs to be a type of AlexaStateModel
        Throws:
        AlexaStateException - Wraps all inner exceptions and gives you context related to handler and model

      • readModel

        public <TModel extends AlexaStateModel> java.util.Optional<TModel> readModel(java.lang.Class<TModel> modelClass)
                                                                      throws AlexaStateException
        Reads out the model from the persistence store of this handler. Depending on the AlexaScopes configured in the AlexaStateSave annotations it will possibly collect data from more than one persistence store. (most likely from the Alexa session and maybe from the permanent persistence store associated with this handler. You are not providing an id with this call. Thus it will look for the single representative without an id.
        Specified by:
        readModel in interface AlexaStateHandler
        Overrides:
        readModel in class AlexaSessionStateHandler
        Type Parameters:
        TModel - Type derived from AlexaStateModel
        Parameters:
        modelClass - Type of the model you would like to read out. It needs to be of type AlexaStateModel.
        Returns:
        A model matching the given type and augmented with all the attributes found in the persistence store.
        Throws:
        AlexaStateException - Wraps all inner exceptions and gives you context related to handler and model

      • readModel

        public <TModel extends AlexaStateModel> java.util.Optional<TModel> readModel(java.lang.Class<TModel> modelClass,
                                                                             java.lang.String id)
                                                                      throws AlexaStateException
        Reads out the model from the persistence store of this handler. Depending on the AlexaScopes configured in the AlexaStateSave annotations it will possibly collect data from more than one persistence store. (most likely from the Alexa session and maybe from the permanent persistence store associated with this handler. You are providing an id with this call. If you never saved the model with this id in the store you won't get anything.
        Specified by:
        readModel in interface AlexaStateHandler
        Overrides:
        readModel in class AlexaSessionStateHandler
        Type Parameters:
        TModel - Type derived from AlexaStateModel
        Parameters:
        modelClass - Type of the model you would like to read out. It needs to be of type AlexaStateModel.
        id - The id of an existing instance of your model in the persistence store.
        Returns:
        A model matching the given type and id. Augmented with all the attributes found in the persistence store.
        Throws:
        AlexaStateException - Wraps all inner exceptions and gives you context related to handler and model
